newsitem.title: USA: Owens to buy Fibreboard in $600 million deal.
newsitem.headline: Owens to buy Fibreboard in $600 million deal.

text.p: Owens Corning, seeking to broaden its building materials product line, said Wednesday was acquiring Fibreboard Corp., which produces vinyl siding and windows, for $600 million, including $85 million in debt.

Owens Corning, a leading producer of high-performance glass fiber composites and building materials, said it had a definitive agreement to acquire all outstanding shares of Fibreboard for $55 a share plus the assumption of debt.
Fibreboard, based in Walnut Creek, Calif., will become a wholly owned subsidiary of Toledo-based Owens Corning when the deal is completed this summer.

Wall Street welcomed the announcement, sending Fibreboard's stock soaring $6.8125 to $54.3125 on the American Stock Exchange, where it was the most heavily traded issue with 3.7 million shares changing hands. Owens Corning added 50 cents to $41.625 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The deal -- Owens Corning's 16th acquisition in the past three years and the largest to date -- will make the company a major producer and marketer of vinyl siding, one of the fastest growing products in the building materials market.
The combination will also provide Fibreboard with resources for continued growth, the announcement said.
"During the last three years Fibreboard has become one of the top producers of vinyl siding and accessories in North America," Owens Corning Chairman Glen H. Hiner said in a statement.

"The company is among the industry's low-cost producers and it has an extensive network of distribution centres for both vinyl siding and windows. These products will become an integral part of our low-maintenance exterior system for the home."

Fibreboard, which also makes other residential and industrial building materials, had sales in 1996 of $469 million. It said that on a pro-forma basis -- assuming its 1997 acquisitions had been completed on Jan.1 -- Fibreboard's sales this year would be expected to be close to $800 million.
Owens Corning, which had 1996 sales of $3.8 billion, said that the acquisition, which is expected to close in July, will add to its earnings starting this year.
Under the agreement, Owens Corning will make a tender offer for all outstanding Fibreboard shares and certain options by June 3, subject to customary conditions, a spokesman said.
Owens Corning said it would finance the transaction using a long-term bank credit facility underwritten by a major financial institution.
